question: Question 1 Euclidean norm (length) of the vector [latex][4\; -2\; -6]^T[/latex] is
solution: Let [latex]X=\begin{bmatrix} 4\\ -2\\ -6 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Norm} \; X&=||X|| \\ &=\sqrt{(4)^2 +(-2)^2 +(-6)^2} \\ &= \sqrt{16+4+36}\\ &= \sqrt{56} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 2 The Laplace transform of [latex]\sinh (at)[/latex] is
solution: [latex]L(\sinh (at))=\frac{a}{s^2-a^2}[/latex]

question: Question 3 The following inequality is true for all x close to 0. [latex]2-\frac{x^2}{3} \lt \frac{xsinx}{1-cosx} \lt 2[/latex] What is the value of [latex]\lim_{x \to 0}\frac{xsinx}{1-cosx}[/latex]?
solution: [latex]\lim_{x \to 0}\frac{x \sin x}{1-\cos x}[/latex] [latex]\lim_{x \to 0}\frac{\frac{\sin x}{x}}{\frac{1-\cos x}{x^2}}=\frac{1}{\frac{1}{2}}=2[/latex]

question: Question 4 What is curl of the vectorfield [latex]2x^2y i+5z^2j-4yzk[/latex]?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{curl}\bar{F}&=\begin{vmatrix} \bar{i} & \bar{j} & \bar{k}\\ \frac{\partial }{\partial x} & \frac{\partial }{\partial y} & \frac{\partial }{\partial z}\\ 2x^2y & 5z^2 & -4yz \end{vmatrix} \\ &=\bar{i}(-4z-10z)-\bar{j}(0-0)+\bar{k}(0-2x^2) \\ &= 14zi-2x^2k \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 5 A closed thin-walled tube has thickness, t, mean enclosed area within the boundary of the centerline of tube's thickness, [latex]A_m[/latex], and shear stress, [latex]\tau[/latex]. Torsional moment of resistance, T, of the section would be
solution: Shear Stress, [latex]\begin{aligned} \tau &=\frac{T}{J}R=\frac{T}{2 \pi R^3 t}R \\ \tau &=\frac{T}{2 \pi R^2 t}=\frac{T}{2 A_m t} \\ T &=2\tau A_mt \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 6 A steel column is restrained against both translation and rotation at one end and is restrained only against rotation but free to translate at the other end. Theoretical and design (IS:800-2007) values, respectively, of effective length factor of the column are
solution: The given support conditions indicates the following support/ end conditions of column [latex]l_{eff}[/latex] as per theoretical conditions = 1.0[latex]l_{o}[/latex] [latex]l_{eff}[/latex] as per IS 800 : 2007 = 1.2 [latex]l_{o}[/latex] Considering the errors that may occur due to construction of supports on site.

question: Question 7 If the fineness modulus of a sample of fine aggregates is 4.3, the mean size of the particles in the sample is between
solution: F.M of mean size 2.36 = 5 F.M of mean size 1.18 = 4 Hence for F.M of 4.3, the mean size of aggregate will be between 1.18 mm and 2.36 mm.

question: Question 8 For a channel section subjected to a downward vertical shear force at its centroid, which one of the following represents the correct distribution of shear stress in flange and web?
solution: Shear flow in horizontal member (flange) is linear with zero at free end and in vertical member (web) it is parabolic.

question: Question 9 Which one of the following options contains ONLY primary air pollutants?
solution: Hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides are considered primary air pollutants.

question: Question 10 Analysis of a water sample revealed that the sample contains the following species. [latex]CO_3^{2-}, Na^{+}, H^{+}[/latex], [latex]PO_4^{3-}, AI^{3+}, H_2CO_3[/latex], [latex]CI^{-}, Ca^{2+},Mg^{2+}[/latex], [latex]HCO_3^{-}, Fe^{2+}, OH^-[/latex] Concentrationsof which of the species will be required to compute alkalinity?
solution: Alkalinity is defined as ability of water to neutralize the acid or hydronium ion [latex]\text{Alkalinity} (A_T) \text{of water} = [HCO_3^-] + [CO_3^{2-}] + [B(OH)_4^-] + [H_3(SiO_4)^-] + [HS^-] + [\text{organic anions}] + [OH^-] - [H^+][/latex] From given options of ions in problem answer is [latex]CO_3^{2-}, H^+, HCO_3^-, OH^-[/latex]

question: Question 11 Structural failures considered in the mechanistic method of bituminous pavement design are

Question 12 A solid sphere of radius, r, and made of material with density, [latex]\rho _s[/latex], is moving through the atmosphere (constant pressure, p)with a velocity, v. The net force ONLY due to atmospheric pressure ([latex]F_p[/latex]) acting on the sphere at any time, t, is
solution:
When object of any shape ( not only sphere) is subjected to uniform pressure over entire surface, the net force is
zero because pressure force at any point is balanced by an equal and opposite force on opposite point.

question: Question 13 The velocity field in a flow system is given by [latex]v=2i+(x+y)j+(xyz)k[/latex]. The acceleration of the fluid at (1,1,2) is
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
\vec{v} &=2\hat{i}(x+y)\hat{j}+xyz\hat{k} \\ 
 u&=2 \\ 
 v&=x+y \\ 
 w&=xyz \\ 
 a_x&=u\frac{\partial u}{\partial x} +v\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}+w\frac{\partial u}{\partial z}+\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}=0\\ 
 a_y&=x+y+2 \\ 
 a_z&= u\frac{\partial w}{\partial x} +v\frac{\partial w}{\partial y}+w\frac{\partial w}{\partial z}+\frac{\partial w}{\partial t}\\ 
 &= 2(yz)+(x+y)(xz)+xyz(xy)\\ 
 a_z&=2yz+x^2z+xyz+x^2y^2z \\ 
&At\;(1,1,2) \\ 
a_y&=11+2=4\\
a_z&=2(1)(2)+(1)^2(2)+(1)(1)(2)+(1)^2(1)^2(2)\\
&=4+2+2+2=10\\
\vec{a}&=4\hat{j}+10\hat{k}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 14 An inflow hydrograph is routed through a reservoir to produce an outflow hydrograph. The peak flow of the inflow hydrograph is [latex]P_I[/latex] and the time of occurrence of the peak is [latex]t_I[/latex]. The peak flow of the outflow hydrograph is [latex]P_O[/latex] and the time of occurrence of the peak is [latex]t_O[/latex]. Which one of the following statements is correct?
solution: The outflow from the reservoir is uncontrolled therefore peak of outflow hydrograph will occur at the junction of inflow and outflow hydrograph. [latex]P_I \gt P_0[/latex] [latex]t_I \lt t_0[/latex]

question: Question 15 An earthen dam of height H is made of cohesive soil whose cohesion and unit weight are c and [latex]\gamma[/latex], respectively. If the factor of safety against cohesionis [latex]F_c[/latex], the Taylor's stability number ([latex]S_n[/latex]) is
solution: [latex]S_n=\frac{c}{\gamma H_c}=\frac{c}{\gamma F_cH} \;\;\;\;\left \{ \because \; F_c=\frac{H_c}{H} \right \}[/latex]

question: Question 16 The notation "SC" as per Indian Standard Soil Classification System refers to
solution: SC[latex]\rightarrow[/latex]Clayey sand

question: Question 17 An anisotropic soil deposit has coefficient of permeability in vertical and horizontal directions as [latex]k_z \; and \; k_x[/latex], respectively. For constructing a flow net, the horizontal dimension of the problem's geometry is transformed by a multiplying factor of
solution: [latex]X=X_T\sqrt{\frac{k_x}{k_z}}[/latex] Transformed horizontal dimension, [latex]X_T=X\sqrt{\frac{k_z}{k_x}}[/latex]

question: Question 18 The value of the function f(x) is given at n distinct values of x and its value is to be interpolated at the point [latex]x^*[/latex], using all the n points. The estimate is obtained first by the Lagrange polynomial, denoted by [latex]I_L[/latex], and then by the Newton polynomial, denoted by [latex]I_N[/latex]. Which one of the following statements is correct?

options.D: No definite relation exists between [latex]I_L \; and \; I_N[/latex]

question: Question 19 The speed-density relationship in a mid-block section of a highway follows the Greenshield's model. If the free flow speed is [latex]v_f[/latex] and the jam density is [latex]k_j[/latex], the maximum flow observed on this section is
solution: maximum flow [latex]=\frac{1}{4}v_fk_j[/latex]

question: Question 20 The degree of static indeterminacy of the plane frame as shown in the figure is ___
solution: Static indeterminacy [latex]D_s = D_{se} + D_{si}-\text{Force releases}[/latex] External indeterminacy, [latex]D_{se} = r - s[/latex] No. of support reactions, r = 7 Number of equilibrium equations, s = 3 [latex]D_{se} = 7-3=4[/latex] Internal indeterminacy [latex]D_{si}= 3\times \text{No of closed boxes}[/latex] [latex]= 3\times 4 = 12[/latex] Force releases = 1 [At the internal hinge] [latex]D_S= 4 + 12 - 1 = 15[/latex]

question: Question 21 The characteristic compressive strength of concrete required in a project is 25MPa and the standard deviation in the observed compressive strength expected at site is 4MPa. The average compressive strength of cubes tested at different water-cement (w/c) ratios using the same material as is used for the project is given in the table. The water-cement ratio (in percent, round off to the lower integer) to be used in the mix is _____
solution: Target mean strength [latex]\begin{aligned} &=f_{ck}+1.65\sigma \\ &= 25+1.65 \times 4.0\\ &= 31.6 \end{aligned}[/latex] Water content required, [latex]=50-\frac{50-45}{35-25}\times (31.6-25)=46.7\%[/latex] say 46% (round off to the lower integer)

question: Question 22 The data from a closed traverse survey PQRS (run in the clockwise direction) are given in the table The closing error for the traverse PQRS (in degrees) is ___
solution:
Assuming it as anticlockwise traverse. Mathematically sum of interior angle for a closed traverse
[latex]=(2n-4)\times 90 = (2 \times 4 -4) \times 90 = 360^{\circ}[/latex] Given sum of interior angles,
[latex]= 88 + 92 + 94 + 89 = 363^{\circ}[/latex] Then error in interior angle [latex]= 363 - 360 = 3^{\circ}[/latex] Note: In this question as per clockwise traverse included angle should be taken as exterior angle. But if we take exterior angle then we get all interior angles more than
[latex]180^{\circ}[/latex].

question: Question 23 A vehicle is moving on a road of grade +4% at a speed of 20 m/s. Consider the coefficient of rolling friction as 0.46 and acceleration due to gravity as 10 [latex]m/s^2[/latex]. On applying brakes to reach a speed of 10 m/s, the required braking distance (in m, round off to nearest integer) along the horizontal, is ______
solution: Given, Upward gradient, G = 4% = 0.04 (upgrade is taken as +ve) Initial speed, [latex]v_1[/latex] = 20 m/s Coefficient of friction (rolling), f = 0.46 Acceleration due to gravity, g = 10 [latex]m/s^2[/latex] Final velocity due to break application (reduced), [latex]v_2[/latex] = 10 m/s Breaking distance, [latex]\begin{aligned} S_b&=\frac{(v_1^2-v_2^2)}{2g(f+G)} \\ &=\frac{(20^2-10^2)}{2 \times 10(0.46+0.04)} \\ &= 30m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 24 The command area of a canal grows only one crop, i.e., wheat. The base period of wheat is 120 days and its total water requirement, [latex]\Delta[/latex], is 40 cm. If the canal discharge is 2 [latex]m^3/s[/latex], the area, in hectares, rounded off to the nearest integer, which could be irrigated (neglectingall losses) is _______
solution: Given data: Base period, B = 120 days Delta of crop, [latex]\Delta = 40 cm[/latex] Discharge, [latex]Q = 2 m^3/s[/latex] Area to be irrigated, A = ? Duty of water, [latex]\Delta =\frac{864 \times B}{\Delta }[/latex] ha/cumec and Area to be irrigated; A = Q x D [latex]\Rightarrow A = 2 m^3/s \times \frac{864 \times 120}{40}\; ha/cumec[/latex] [latex]A = 5184\; ha[/latex]

question: Question 25 Construction of a new building founded on a clayey soil was completed in January 2010. In January 2014, the average consolidation settlement of the foundation in clay was recorded as 10 mm. The ultimate consolidation settlement was estimated in design as 40 mm. Considering double drainage to occur at the clayey soil site, the expected consolidation settlement in January 2019 (in mm, round off to the nearestinteger) will be ________
solution: Jan. 2010 - Jan. 2014 (4 years) Settlement is 10 mm [latex]\Delta H = 40 mm[/latex] 2 - way drainage Settlement in Jan. 2019 (in 9 years) = ? In 4 years, [latex]\begin{aligned} \%U &=\frac{\Delta h}{\Delta H}\times 100 \\ &= \frac{10}{40}\times 100=25\%\\ T_v&=C_v\frac{t}{d^2}\;\;\;\because \%U \lt 60\% \\ T_v&=\frac{\pi}{4}U^2 \\ \frac{\pi}{4}\left ( \frac{25}{100} \right )^2&=\frac{C_v}{d^2} \times 4 \; years...(1) \end{aligned}[/latex] In 9 years [latex]\begin{aligned} T_v&=C_v\frac{t}{d^2}\\ &=\frac{\pi }{4} \times\frac{(0.25)^2}{4}\times 9 \; \text{years}\\ &=0.11044\\ \because \; (T_v)_{60}&=0.283 \\ \therefore \;\%U &\lt 60\%\\ \therefore \;T_v&=0.11044=\frac{\pi}{4}U^2\\ \%U&=0.3749=37.499\%\\ \%U&=\frac{\Delta h}{\Delta H} \times 100\\ &=\frac{\Delta h}{40mm}\times 100=37.499\\ \Delta h&=14.99mm=15mm \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 26 The probability density function of a continuous random variable distributed uniformly between x and y (for [latex]y \gt x[/latex]) is
solution: Probability density function of uniform distribution is [latex]f(x)=\frac{1}{y-x}[/latex]

question: Question 27 Consider the hemi-spherical tank of radius 13 m as shown in the figure. What is the volume of water (in [latex]m^3[/latex]) when the depth of water at the centre of the tank is 6 m?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Volume of water}&=\frac{1}{3}\pi h^2(3r-h)\\ &=\frac{1}{3}\pi \times 6^2 \times (3 \times 13 -6)\\ &=396\pi \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 28 An ordinary differential equation is given below. [latex]\left ( \frac{dy}{dx} \right )(x lnx)=y[/latex] The solution for the above equation is (Note: K denotes a constant in the options)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dx}(x \ln x) &=y \\ \frac{dy}{y}&=\frac{dx}{x \ln x} \\ \int \frac{dy}{y}&=\int \frac{1}{x \ln x}dx+ \ln K \\ \ln x&=t \\ \frac{1}{x}dx&=dt \\ \ln y&= \int \frac{dy}{t}+ \ln K\\ \ln y&=\ln t+ \ln K \\ \ln y&=Kt \\ y&=K \ln x \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 29 For a plane stress problem, the state of stress at a point P is represented by the stress element as shown in figure. By how much angle ([latex]\theta[/latex]) in degrees the stress element should be rotated in order to get the planes of maximum shear stress?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma _x&=80\\ \sigma _y&=-20\\ \sigma _z&=-25 \end{aligned}[/latex] Angle of plane of max shear [latex]\begin{aligned} \theta &=\theta _p+45^{\circ}\\ \tan 2\theta _p&=\frac{2\tau _{xy}}{\sigma _x-\sigma _y}\\ &=\frac{-50}{100}\\ \theta _p&=-13.28^{\circ}\\ \therefore \;\;\theta &=31.71^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 30 The critical bending compressive stress in the extreme fibre of a structural steel section is 1000 MPa. It is given that the yield strength of the steel is 250 MPa, width of flange is 250 mm and thickness of flange is 15 mm. As per the provisions of IS:8002007, the non-dimensional slenderness ratio of the steel cross-section is
solution: [latex]\lambda =\sqrt{\frac{f_y}{f_{cr}}}=\sqrt{\frac{250}{1000}}=0.5[/latex]

question: Question 31 In the context of provisions relating to durability of concrete, consider the following assertions: Assertion (1): As per IS 456-2000, air entrainment to the extent of 3% to 6% is required for concrete exposed to marine environment. Assertion (2): The equivalent alkali content (in terms of [latex]Na_2O[/latex] equivalent) for a cement containing 1% and 0.6% of [latex]Na_2O[/latex] and [latex]K_2O[/latex], respectively, is approximately 1.4% (rounded to 1 decimal place). Which one of the following statements is CORRECT?
solution:
(1) As per clause 8.2.2.3 of IS 456-2000, entrained air percentage of 3 to 6% is required to resist freezing and thawing, i.e. not for marine environment. Hence, Assertion (1) is wrong Equivalent alkali content is terms of [latex]Na_2O[/latex] [latex]
= [Na_2 O] + 0.685 [K_2 O][/latex] [latex]
= 1 + 0.685 \times 0.6 = 1.41 \%[/latex] Hence, Assertion (2) is correct

options.A: Assertion (1) is FALSE and Assertion (2) is TRUE
options.B: Assertion (1) is TRUE and Assertion (2) is FALSE
options.C: Both Assertion (1) and Assertion (2) are FALSE
options.D: Both Assertion (1) and Assertion (2) are TRUE

question: Question 32 Chlorine is used as the disinfectant in a municipal water treatment plant. It achieves 50 percent of disinfection efficiency measured in terms of killing the indicator microorganisms (E-Coli) in 3 minutes. The minimum time required to achieve 99 percent disinfection efficiency would be

Question 33 A camera with a focal length of 20 cm fitted in an aircraft is used for taking vertical aerial photographs of a terrain. The average elevation of the terrain is 1200 m above mean sea level (MSL). What is the height above MSL at which an aircraft must fly in order to get the aerial photographs at a scale of 1:8000?
solution: Given focal length = 20 cm as we know scale of vertical photograph [latex]=\frac{f}{H-h_{avg}}[/latex] its given as 1 : 8000 Hence, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{f}{H-h_{avg}} &=\frac{1}{8000} \\ \frac{20 cm}{(H-1200) \times 100cm}&=\frac{1}{8000} \\ \Rightarrow \;\;H &=2800m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 34 A flexible pavement has the following class of loads during a particular hour of the day. i. 80 buses with 2-axles (each axle load of 40 kN); ii. 160 trucks with 2-axles (front and rear axle loads of 40 kN and 80 kN, respectively) The equivalent standard axle load repetitions for this vehicle combination as per IRC:37-2012 would be
solution: (i) 80 buses with 2 axle with 40 kN each. [latex]N_1=80 \times 2=160[/latex] [latex]L_1=40kN[/latex] [latex]160 \text{ truks} \left\{\begin{matrix} \text{Front axle}\rightarrow 40kN\\ \text{Rear axle}\rightarrow 80kN \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] [latex]N_1=160,\;L_1=40kN[/latex] [latex]N_2=160,\;L_2=80kN[/latex] [latex]\text{Total no. of repetitions}\left\{\begin{matrix} &\text{For}\; 40kN=160+160=320\\ &\text{For}\; 80kN=160 \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] [latex]N_1=320,\;L_1=40kN[/latex] [latex]N_2=160,\;L_2=80kN[/latex] As per 4th power law [latex]\begin{aligned} N_s&=N_1\left ( \frac{L_1}{L_5} \right )^4 +N_2 \left ( \frac{L_2}{L_5} \right )^4 \\ &= 320\left ( \frac{40}{80} \right )^4+160\left ( \frac{80}{80} \right )^4\\ &= 20+160=180 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 35 The inverse of the matrix [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3 & 4\\ 4& 3 & 1\\ 1 & 2 & 4 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] is
solution: det (A) = 2(12 - 2) - 3 (16 - 1) + 4 (8 -3) = 2(10) - 3 (15) + 4(5) det (A) = - 5 Minor of 2 = 12 - 2 = 10 Minor of 3 = 16 - 1 = 15 Minor of 4 = 8- 3 = 5 Minor of 4 = 12 - 8 = 4 Minor of 3 = 8 - 4 = 4 Minor of 1 = 4 - 3 = 1 Minor of 1 = 3 - 12 = -9 Minor of 2 = 2 - 16 = -14 Minor of 4 = 6 - 12 = -6 Cofactors of [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} 10 &-15 &5 \\ -4& 4 & -1\\ -9& 14 &-6 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{adj} \;A &= (\text{cofactors of A})^T \\ \text{adj} \;A &=\begin{bmatrix} 10 &-4 &-9 \\ -15& 4 &14 \\ 5& -1 &-6 \end{bmatrix} \\ \therefore \;A^{-1}=\frac{\text{adj} \;A}{|A|} &=\frac{-1}{5}\begin{bmatrix} 10 &-4 &-9 \\ -15& 4 &14 \\ 5& -1 &-6 \end{bmatrix}\\ A^{-1}&=\begin{bmatrix} -2 &\frac{4}{5} &\frac{9}{5} \\ 3& \frac{-4}{5} & \frac{-14}{5}\\ -1& \frac{1}{5} &\frac{6}{5} \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 A long uniformly distributed load of 10 kN/m and a concentrated load of 60 kN are moving together on the beam ABCD shown in the figure. The relative positions of the two loads are not fixed. The maximum shear force (in kN, round off to the nearest integer) caused at the internal hinge B due to the two loads is _____
solution: ILD for [latex]V_B[/latex] Maximum shear [latex]V_B=-\left [ \left ( \frac{1}{2}\times 2 \times 1 \times 10 \right )+(60 \times 1) \right ]=-70kN[/latex]

question: Question 37 A plane frame shown in the figure has linear elastic springs at node H. The spring constants are [latex]k_x=k_y=5 \times 10^5kN/m[/latex] and [latex]k_\theta =3 \times 10^5kNm/rad[/latex]. For the externally applied moment of 30 kNm at node F, the rotation (in degrees, round off to 3 decimals) observed in the rotational spring at node H is_____
solution: No moment can be taken by segment FE. [latex]\therefore \;\;M_{FE}=0[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} M_\theta &=k_\theta \times \theta \\ 30kNm&=3 \times 10^5 \times \theta \\ \theta &=1 \times 10^{-4} \; \text{radians} \\ &=0.0057^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 38 A rolled I-section beam is supported on a 75 mm wide bearing plate as shown in the figure. Thicknesses of flange and web of the I-section are 20 mm and 8 mm, respectively. Root radius of the I-section is 10 mm. Assume: material yield stress, [latex]f_y=250 MPa[/latex] and partial safety factor for material, [latex]\gamma _{mo}=1.10[/latex]. As per IS: 800-2007, the web bearing strength (in kN, round off to 2 decimal places) of the beam is ________
solution: Web bearing strength [latex]\begin{aligned} &=[b+2.5(t_f+R)]\times t_w \times \frac{f_y}{\gamma _{mo}} \\ &= [75+2.5(20+10)] \times 8 \times \frac{250}{1.1}\\ &= 272.73kN \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 39 When aspecimen of M25 concrete is loaded to a stress level of 12.5 MPa, a strain of [latex]500 \times 10^{-6}[/latex] is recorded. If this load is allowed to stand for a long time, the strain increasesto [latex]1000 \times 10^{-6}[/latex]. In accordance with the provisions of IS:456-2000, considering the long-term effects, the effective modulus of elasticity of the concrete (in MPa) is________
solution: Effective modulus of elastic [latex]\begin{aligned} E_{ce}&=\frac{E_c}{1+\theta } \\ E_c&= 5000\sqrt{f_{ck}}\\ &= 5000\sqrt{25}\\ &=25000MPa \end{aligned}[/latex] Creep coefcient [latex]\begin{aligned} \theta &=\frac{\text{creep strain}}{\text{elastic strain}} \\ &= \frac{\text{longterm strain - elastic strain}}{\text{elastic strain}}\\ &=\frac{(1000 \times 10^{-6})-(500 \times 10^{-6})}{(500 \times 10^{-6})}=1\\ \therefore \;\;E_{ce}&=\frac{25000}{1+1}=12500MPa \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 40 A water treatment plant treats 6000 [latex]m^3[/latex] of water per day. As a part of the treatment process, discrete particles are required to be settled in a clarifier. A column test indicates that an overflow rate of 1.5 m per hour would produce the desired removal of particles through settling in the clarifier having a depth of 3.0 m. The volume of the required clarifier, (in [latex]m^3[/latex], round off to 1 decimal place) would be _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Design discharge, }\\ Q_0&=6000m^3/d\\ \text{Overflow rate}\\ OFR(v_s)&=1.5m/hr\\ SA&=\frac{Q_0}{OFR}\\ \text{Volume,}\; V&=SA \times \text{Depth}(H)\\ &=\frac{Q_0}{OFR} \times H\\ &=\frac{6000 \times 3}{1.5 \times 24}=500m^3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 Raw municipal solid waste (MSW) collected from a city contains 70% decomposable material that can be converted to methane. The water content of the decomposable material is 35%. An elemental analysis of the decomposable material yields the following mass percent. C : H : O : N : other = 44 : 6 : 43 : 0.8 : 6.2 The methane production of the decomposable material is governed by the following stoichiometric relation [latex]C_aH_bO_cN_d+nH_2O\rightarrow mCH_4+sCO_2+dNH_3[/latex] Given atomic weights: C=12, H=1, O=16, N=14. The mass of methane produced (in grams, round off to 1 decimal place) per kg of raw MSW will be ______
solution: Let 1 kg of row municipal solid waste (MSW) Decomposable material = 70% of 1 kg = 0.7 kg Water content = 35% Weight of solids in MSW [latex]=\left(\frac{100-35}{100}\right)\times0.7=0.455\;\mathrm{kg}=455\;\mathrm{gms}[/latex] Given: C:H:O:N: other = 44 : 6: 43: 0.8:6.2[latex]\begin{array}{l}\mathrm{Weight}\;\mathrm{of}\;\mathrm C=\frac{(44)}{\left(44+6+43+0.8+6.2\right)}\times455=200.2\;\mathrm{gms}\\\mathrm{Weight}\;\mathrm{of}\;\mathrm H=\frac{\left(6\right)}{\left(44+6+43+0.8+6.2\right)}\times455=27.3\;\mathrm{gms}\\\mathrm{Weight}\;\mathrm{of}\;\mathrm O=\frac{(43)}{\left(44+6+43+0.8+6.2\right)}\times455=195.6\;\mathrm{gms}\\\mathrm{Weight}\;\mathrm{of}\;\mathrm N=\frac{\left(0.8\right)}{\left(44+6+43+0.8+6.2\right)}\times455=3.64\;\mathrm{gms}\\\Rightarrow12\mathrm a=200.2\Rightarrow\mathrm a=16.68\\1\times\mathrm b=27.3\Rightarrow\mathrm b=27.3\\16\times\mathrm c=195.6\Rightarrow\mathrm c=12.225\\14\times\mathrm d=3.64\Rightarrow\mathrm d=0.26\\\mathrm{Now},\;\mathrm{balancing}\;\mathrm{the}\;\mathrm{given}\;\mathrm{stoichiometic}\;\mathrm r\times\mathrm n\\{\mathrm C}_{\mathrm a}{\mathrm H}_{\mathrm b}{\mathrm O}_{\mathrm C}{\mathrm N}_{\mathrm d}+{\mathrm{nH}}_2\mathrm O\rightarrow{\mathrm{mCH}}_4+{\mathrm{SCO}}_2+{\mathrm{dNn}}_3\\12\mathrm a=12\mathrm m+12\mathrm s\Rightarrow12\mathrm m+12\mathrm s=200.2\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\left(12\mathrm a=200.2\right)\\\mathrm b+2\mathrm n=4\mathrm m+3\mathrm d\Rightarrow4\mathrm m-2\mathrm n=26.52\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\left(6=27.3\right)\\16\mathrm c+16\mathrm n=325\Rightarrow\mathrm n=25-12.225\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\left(16\mathrm c=195.6\right)\\\therefore\;\;\;\;\;4\mathrm m-2\left(2\mathrm s-12.225\right)=26.52\\\Rightarrow4\mathrm m-4\mathrm s=2.07\\\Rightarrow12\mathrm m-12\mathrm s=6.21\\\mathrm{Also},\;12\mathrm m+12\mathrm s=200.2\\\Rightarrow\mathrm m=8.6\\\therefore\;\;\mathrm{Mass}\;\mathrm{of}\;\mathrm{methane}\;\mathrm{produced} \\ =16\times\mathrm m=16\times8.6=137.6\;\mathrm{gms}\end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 42 Consider the reactor shown in the figure. The flow rate through the reactor is [latex]Q \; m^3/h[/latex]. The concentrations (in mg/L) of a compound in the influent and effluent are [latex]C_0[/latex] and C, respectively. The compound is degraded in the reactor following the first order reaction. The mixing condition of the reactor can be varied such that the reactor becomes either a completely mixed flow reactor (CMFR) or a plug-flow reactor (PFR). The length of the reactor can be adjusted in these two mixing conditions to [latex]L_{CMFR}[/latex] and [latex]L_{PFR}[/latex] while keeping the cross-section of the reactor constant. Assuming steady stateand for [latex]C/C_0 =0.8[/latex], the value of [latex]L_{CMFR}/L_{PFR}[/latex] (round off to 2 decimal places) is _______
solution: Hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides are considered primary air pollutants. [latex]c=\frac{c_0}{1+kt}[/latex] For (PFR) plug flow reactor [latex]\begin{aligned} c&=c_0e^{-kt} \\ \text{As}\;\; c/c_0 &=0.8 \\ \text{For CMFR} \;\; 0.8&=\frac{1}{1+kt_{CMFR}} \\ \Rightarrow \;\;t_{CMFR} &=\frac{0.25}{k} \\ \text{For PFR} \;\; 0.8&=e^{-kt_{PFR}} \\ \Rightarrow \;\; t_{PFR}&=\frac{0.22314}{k} \end{aligned}[/latex] Now for steady state [latex]\begin{aligned} v&=\text{constant}\\ L&=vt\\ So, \;\;\frac{L_{CMFR}}{L_{PFR}}&=\frac{vt_{CMFR}}{vt_{PFR}}\\ &=\frac{0.25}{0.22314}=1.12 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 43 A series of perpendicular offsets taken from a curved boundary wall to a straight survey line at an interval of 6m are 1.22, 1.67, 2.04, 2.34, 2.14, 1.87, and 1.15 m. The area (in [latex]m^2[/latex], round off to 2 decimal places) bounded by the survey line, curved boundary wall, the first and the last offsets, determined using Simpson's rule, is _______

Question 44 The uniform arrival and uniform service rates observed on an approach road to a signalized intersection are 20 and 50 vehicles/minute, respectively. For this signal, the red time is 30 s, the effective green time is 30 s, and the cycle length is 60 s. Assuming that initially there are no vehicles in the queue, the average delay per vehicle using the approach road during a cycle length(in s, round off to 2 decimal places) is ______
solution: Arrival rate = 20 veh/min Service rate = 50 veh/min R = 30 sec, [latex]G_i[/latex] = 30 sec, Cycle length = 60sec Time corresponding to which no. of arrival becomes same as no. of departure. [latex]\begin{aligned} 20 \times (R+t) &=50t \\ 20 \times (30+t)&=50t \\ t &=\frac{600}{30}=20sec \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Avg. Delay}&=\left ( \frac{\text{Area under arrival line}-\text{Area under departure line}}{\text{Cumulative number of vehicle arrival}} \right ) \\ &=\left ( \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times 16.67 \times 50 -\frac{1}{2} \times 16.67 \times 25}{20} \right )\\ &=12.50sec \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 45 A broad gauge railway line passes through a horizontal curved section (radius = 875 m) of length 200 m. The allowable speed on this portion is 100 km/h. For calculating the cant, consider the gauge as centre-to-centre distance between the rail heads, equal to 1750 mm. The maximum permissible cant (in mm, round off to 1 decimal place) with respect to the centre-to-centre distance between the rail heads is_____
solution: For a railway track [latex]\begin{array}{l}\mathrm{Allowable}\;\mathrm{cant}=\frac{\mathrm G.\mathrm V^2}{127\mathrm R}\;\;\mathrm{where}\;\mathrm V\;\mathrm{is}\;\mathrm{in}\;\mathrm{km}/\mathrm{hr}=100\\\mathrm{Allowable}\;\mathrm{cant}=\frac{1750\times100^2}{127\times895}=157.5\;\mathrm{mm}\end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 46 The speed-density relationship of a highway is given as u=100-0.5k where, u = speed in km per hour, k = density in vehicles per km. The maximum flow (in vehicles per hour, round off to the nearest integer) is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} u&=100-0.5k\\ u&=100\left [ 1-\frac{k}{(100/0.5)} \right ]\\ \text{Green shield model}\;\;u&=V_f\left ( 1-\frac{k}{k_j} \right )\\ V_f&=\text{free mean speed}\\ &=100kmph\\ k_j&=\text{Jam density }\\ &=\frac{100}{0.5}=200 veh./km\\ \text{Max flow.}\;\;q_{max}&=\frac{1}{4}V_fk_j\\ &=\frac{1}{4} \times 100 \times 200=5000veh./hr \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 47 A confined aquifer of 15 m constant thickness is sandwiched between two aquicludes as shown in the figure. The heads indicated by two piezometers P and Q are 55.2 m and 34.1 m, respectively. The aquifer has a hydraulic conductivity of 80 m/day and its effective porosity is 0.25. If the distance between the piezometers is 2500 m, the time taken by the water to travel through the aquifer from piezometer location P to Q (in days,round off to 1 decimal place) is______
solution: Discharge velocity, [latex]\begin{aligned} V&=ki\\ V&=k\frac{h_1-h_2}{L}\\ &=80 \left ( \frac{55.2-34.1}{2500} \right )\\ &=0.6752 m/day\\ &\text{Porosity}, n =0.25\\ &\therefore \;\;\text{Seepage velocity,}\\ V_s&=\frac{V}{n}=\frac{0.6752}{0.25}\\ &=2.7008 m/day\\ \text{Time taken}&=\frac{L}{V_s}\\ &=\frac{2500}{2.7008}=925.65 days \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 48 At the foot of a spillway, water flows at a depth of 23 cm with a velocity of 8.1 m/s, as shown in the figure. The flow enters as an M-3 profile in the long wide rectangular channel with bed slope = [latex]\frac{1}{1800}[/latex] and Manning's n= 0.015. A hydraulic jump is formed at a certain distance from the foot of the spillway. Assume the acceleration due to gravity, g = 9.81 [latex]m/s^2[/latex]. Just before the hydraulic jump, the depth of flow [latex]y_1[/latex]
 (in m, round off to 2 decimal places) is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y &=0.23m \\ V&=8.1m/s \\ q&=Vy=0.23 \times 8.1 \\ &= 1.863 m^3/s-m\\ S_0&=\frac{1}{800} \\ D&=0.015 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]y_n=[/latex] Normal depth of flow R = y for wide rectangular channel By Manning's equation [latex]\begin{aligned} q&=\frac{y_n}{n}R^{2/3}S_0^{1/2} \\ 1.863&=\frac{y_n^{5/3}}{0.015} \times \left ( \frac{1}{1800} \right )^{1/2} \\ y_n&= 1.108m \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]y_1[/latex] is conjugate depth of [latex]y_0[/latex], [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{y_1}{y_n}&=\frac{-1+\sqrt{1+8Fr_n^2}}{2} \\ \because &\;\;\left ( Fr_n^2=\frac{q^2}{gy_n^3} \right ) \\ y_1&=\frac{-1+\sqrt{1+8 \times \frac{1.863^2}{9.81 \times 1.108^3}}}{2} \times 1.108\\ &=0.418m\simeq 0.42m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 49 Two identical pipes (i.e., having the same length, same diameter, and same roughness) are used to withdraw water from a reservoir. In the first case, they are attached in series and discharge freely into the atmosphere. In the second case, they are attached in parallel and also discharge freely into the atmosphere. Neglecting all minor losses, and assuming that the friction factor is same in both the cases, the ratio of the discharge in the parallel arrangement to that in the series arrangement (round off to 2 decimal places) is ______
solution: Given: Two identical pipes of same length (L), diameter (D) and roughness ([latex]k_s[/latex]). First case (series) Assume height of reservoir = H [latex]\begin{aligned} H &=h_{f1} +h_{f2}\;\;\;...(i)\\ H&=2h_{f1} \;\;\;(\because h_{f1}=h_{f2})\\ H&=2\left ( \frac{8Q_1^2}{\pi^2 g} \times \frac{fL}{D^5} \right ) \end{aligned}[/latex] Second case (Parallel) [latex]H =\frac{8}{\pi^2 g}\left ( \frac{Q_2}{2} \right )^2 \times \frac{fL}{D^5}\;\;\;...(ii)[/latex] By eq. (i) and (ii) [latex]\begin{aligned} 2\left ( \frac{8Q_1^2}{\pi^2 g} \times \frac{fL}{D^5} \right )&=\frac{8}{\pi^2 g}\left ( \frac{Q_2}{2} \right )^2 \times \frac{fL}{D^5}\\ \frac{Q_2}{Q_1}&=\sqrt{8}=2.83 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 50 The ordinates, u, of a 2-hour unit hydrograph (i.e., for 1 cm of effective rain), for a catchment are shown in the table. A 6-hour storm occurs over the catchment such that the effective rainfall intensity is 1 cm/hour for the first two hours, zero for the next two hours, and 0.5 cm/hour for the last two hours. If the base flow is constant at 5 [latex]m^3/s[/latex], the peak flow due to this storm (in [latex]m^3/s[/latex],round off to 1 decimal place) will be _____
solution: Rainfall excess in 1st two hours, [latex]R_1=1cm/hr \times 2 hr=2cm[/latex] Rainfall excess in 2nd two hours [latex]R_2=0[/latex] Rainfall excess in 3rd two hours, [latex]R_3=0.5cm/hr \times 2 hr=1cm[/latex]

question: Question 51 The dimensions of a soil sampler are given in the table. For this sampler, the outside clearance ratio (in percent, round off to 2 decimal places) is ______
solution: Outside clearance [latex]=\left ( \frac{D_2 -D_4}{D_4} \right ) \times 100[/latex] Outside clearance [latex]=\left ( \frac{100 -90}{90} \right ) \times 100 =11.11\%[/latex]

question: Question 52 A 2mx 4m rectangular footing has to carry a uniformly distributed load of 120 kPa. As per the 2:1 dispersion method of stress distribution, the increment in vertical stress (in kPa) at a depth of 2m below the footing is ________
solution: The area of rectangular footing = 2 m x 4 m q = 120 kPa as 2:1 dispersion method of stress distribution [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta \bar{\sigma }&=\frac{q(B \times L)}{(B+2nZ)(L+2nZ)}\\ &=\frac{120 \times 2 \times 4}{(2+2 \times \frac{1}{2}\times 2)(4+2 \times \frac{1}{2}\times 2)}\\ \Delta \bar{\sigma }&=40kPa \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 Constant head permeability tests were performed on two soil specimens, S1 and S2. The ratio of height of the two specimens ([latex]L_{S1}:L_{S2}[/latex]) is 1.5, the ratio of the diameter of specimens ([latex]D_{S1}:D_{S2}[/latex]) is 0.5, and the ratio of the constant head ([latex]h_{S1}:h_{S2}[/latex]) applied on the specimens is 2.0. If the discharge from both the specimens is equal, the ratio of the permeability of the soil specimens ([latex]k_{S1}:k_{S2}[/latex]) is ____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{L_{s1}}{L_{s2}}&=1.5\\ \frac{D_{s1}}{D_{s2}}&=0.5\\ \frac{h_{s1}}{h_{s2}}&=2\\ \frac{k_{s1}}{k_{s2}}&=? \end{aligned}[/latex] Discharge is same. [latex]\begin{aligned} k_1i_1A_1&=k_2i_2A_2\\ k_1\frac{h_{s1}}{L_{s1}} \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times D_{s1}^2&=k_2\frac{h_{s2}}{L_{s2}} \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times D_{s2}^2\\ \frac{k_{s1}}{k_{s2}}&=\frac{L_{s1}}{L_{s2}} \times \frac{h_{s2}}{h_{s1}} \times \frac{D_{s2}^2}{D_{s1}^2}\\ &=1.5 \times \frac{1}{2} \times \left ( \frac{1}{0.5} \right )^2=3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 A timber pile of length 8 m and diameter 0.2 m is driven with a 20 kN drop hammer, falling freely from a height of 1.5 m. The total penetration of the pile in the last 5 blows is 40 mm. Use the Engineering News Record expression. Assumea factor of safety of 6 and empirical factor (allowing reduction in the theoretical set, due to energy losses) of 2.5cm. The safe load carrying capacity of the pile (in kN, round off to 2 decimal places) is _______
solution: L = 8 m; d = 0.2 m, 20 kN = W ( drop hammer) H = 1.5 m Penetration in 5 blows = 40 mm [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \; \text{in 1 blow}&=\frac{40}{5}=8mm=0.8cm\\ Q_{safe}&=\left ( \frac{WH}{s+c} \right )\times \frac{1}{FOS}\\ &=\frac{1}{6}\left [ \frac{20kN \times (1.5 \times 100)}{0.8cm+2.5cm} \right ]\\ Q_{safe}&=151.51kN \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 55 A square footing of 2 m sides rests on the surface of a homogeneous soil bed having the properties: cohesion c=24 kPa, angle of internal friction [latex]\phi =25^{\circ}[/latex], and unit weight [latex]\gamma =18kN/m^3[/latex]. Terzaghi's bearing capacity factors for [latex]\phi =25^{\circ}[/latex] are [latex]N_c=25.1, N_q=12.7[/latex], [latex]N_{\gamma}=9.7, N_c'=14.8,N_q'=5.6[/latex], and [latex]N_{\gamma}'=3.2[/latex]. The ultimate bearing capacity of the foundation (in kPa, round off to 2 decimal places) is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} c &=24kN/m^2 ,\; \phi =25^{\circ} \\ \gamma &=18 kN/m^3 ,\; N_c =25.1 \\ N_q&=12.7 ,\; N_\gamma =9.7 \\ N_c' &=14.8 ,\; N_q'=5.6 \\ N_\gamma '&=3.2 \\ &\text{Square footing}\\ B&=2m ,\;L=2m\\ D_f&=0\;\; (\text{Surface footing})\\ \text{since,}\;\;\phi &=25^{\circ} \lt 28^{\circ}\rightarrow \text{Assume local shear failure.}\\ \text{Hence,}\;\;&=c_m=\frac{2}{3}c=\frac{2}{3} \times 24=16kN/m^2 \end{aligned}[/latex] Ultimate bearing capacity of square footing, [latex]\begin{aligned} q_u&=1.3c_mN_c' +\gamma D_fN_q'+0.4\gamma BN_\gamma '\\ q_u&=1.3\times 16 \times 14.8+0+0.4 \times 18 \times 2 \times 3.2\\ q_u&=307.84+46.08\\ q_u&=353.92kN/m^2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 56 Daytime temperature in Delhi can ______  [latex]40^{\circ}C[/latex].
Question 57 The growth rate of ABC Motors in 2017 was the same ________ XYZ Motors in 2016.

Question 58 Suresh wanted to lay a new carpet in his new mansion with an area of 70 x 55 sq.mts. However an area of 550 sq. mts. had to be left out for flower pots. If the cost carpet is Rs.50  sq. mts. how much money (in Rs.) will be spent by Suresh for the carpet now?

Question 59 A retaining wall with measurements 30 m x  12 m x 6 m was constructed with bricks of dimensions  8 cm x 6 cm x 6 cm. If 60% of the wall consists of bricks,the number of bricks used for the construction is _______ lakhs.
Question 60 Hema Das was_____ only Indian athlete to win _______ gold for India.

Question 61 Mohan, the manager, wants his four workers to work in pairs. No pair should work for more than 5 hours. Ram and John have worked together for 5 hours. Krishna and Amir have worked as a team for 2 hours. Krishna does not want to work with Ram. Whom should Mohan allot to work with John, if he wants all the workers to continue working?

Question 62 Population of state X increased by x%  and the population of state Y increased by y% from 2001 to 2011. Assume that x is greater than y. Let P be the ratio of the population of state X to state Y in a given year. The percentage increase in P from 2001 to 2011 is ________

Question 63 The Newspaper reports that over 500 hectares of tribal land spread across 28 tribal settlements in Mohinitampuram forest division have already been "alienated". A top forest official said, "First the tribals are duped out of their land holdings. Second, the families thus rendered landless are often forced to encroach further into the forests". On the basis of the information available in the paragraph,______ is /are responsible for duping the tribals.

options.D: it can not be inferred who

question: Question 64 An oil tank can be filled by pipe X in 5 hours and pipe Y in 4 hours, each pump working on its own. When the oil tank is full and the drainage hole is open, the oil is drained in 20 hours. If initially the tank was empty and someone started the two pups together but left the drainage hole open, how many hours will it take for the tank to be filled? (Assume that the rate of drainage is independent of the Head)

Question 65 "popular Hindi fiction, despite - or perhaps because of - its wide reach, often does not appear in our cinema. As ideals that viewers are meant to look up to rather identify with, Hindi film protagonists usually read books of aspirational value: textbook, English books, or high-value literature." Which one of the following CANNOT be inferred from the paragraph above?

options.A: Though popular Hindi fiction has wide reach, it often does not appear in the movies
options.B: Protagonists in Hindi movies, being ideals for viewers, read only books of aspirational value
options.C: Textbooks, English books or high literature have  aspirational value, but not popular Hindi fiction
options.D: People do not look up to writers of textbook, English books or high-value literature
